bibl.title: Telegram from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, September 12, 1951

div1.p: Hench pays homage to Walter Reed on his 100th birthday.

div1.head: Telegram from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, September 12, 1951
div1.opener:
COPY
WESTERN
UNION
1206
W. P. MARSHALL, PRESIDENT
Send the following message, subject to the terms on back hereof, which are hereby agreed to
MRS BLOSSOM REED BLUE RIDGE SUMMIT, PENNSYLVANIA
div1.p:
I JOIN THE COUNTLESS THRONG WHO HONOR YOUR FATHER'S MEMORY ON THIS
HUNDREDTH ANNIVERSARY OF HIS BIRTH. DURING HIS FINAL ILLNESS HE REGRETTED
THAT HE HAD SO LITTLE TO LEAVE HIS FAMILY. TIME HAS SHOWN HIS HUMBLE
APPRAISAL OF HIS ESTATE TO HAVE BEEN ONE OF THE GREATEST UNDER-EVALUATIONS
OF HISTORY. BY CONTROLLING ONE OF THE GREAT PLAGUES HE LEFT TO YOU AND
TO THE WORLD'S FAMILY AT LARGE A PRICELESS HERITAGE AND AN IMMORTAL NAME AS
ONE OF THE GREAT BENEFACTORS OF MANKIND. MRS HENCH, MARY, AND I WERE SO
PLEASED BY YOUR LOVELY WEDDING GIFT. DID IT BELONG TO YOUR MOTHER?
